step1.sentence: After two years of struggling, the small bakery finally managed to turn a profit last quarter.

step2.story: Maya poured her savings into a tiny coffee shop on a quiet street corner. For the first eighteen months, she barely broke even, reinvesting every dollar into better beans and cozy furniture. When she finally turned a profit in December, she sat alone after closing and cried happy tears into her favorite mug.

step3.story: Daniel quit his corporate job at thirty-five to open an independent bookstore, something everyone around him called reckless. The first year was brutal — rent ate through his savings, and some months he wondered if he would have to close the doors for good. He started hosting weekend reading clubs and partnering with local schools to bring children in for story hours. Slowly, word spread, and the shop became a neighborhood gathering place. By the end of the second year, he was stunned to realize he had actually turned a profit. Standing behind the counter on a busy Saturday morning, he knew every sleepless night had been worth it.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: '이익을 돌리다'라는 뜻으로, 수입이 지출을 넘어서 실제로 돈을 벌게 되는 것을 의미합니다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 사업이나 투자에서 비용을 제하고 실제 수익이 발생했을 때 사용합니다. 특히 한동안 손실을 보다가 흑자로 전환되는 순간을 강조할 때 자주 쓰입니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 'turn'은 '전환하다, 방향을 바꾸다'라는 의미로, 손실 상태에서 이익 상태로 '전환'한다는 비유에서 유래했습니다. 비즈니스 영어에서 오랫동안 사용되어 온 표현입니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 단순히 돈을 번다는 뜻보다는 '적자에서 흑자로 전환'하는 뉘앙스가 강합니다. 주로 사업, 투자, 프로젝트 등 비즈니스 맥락에서 사용되며, 중립적이고 다소 격식 있는 표현입니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: The startup didn't turn a profit until its third year of operation.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 그 스타트업은 운영 3년 차가 되어서야 비로소 이익을 냈다.
